applicability.title: Applicability
applicability.content:
This Act applies to the processing of digital personal data within the territory of India where:

(i) such personal data is collected in digital form; or
(ii) such personal data, collected in non-digital form, is digitised subsequently.

This Act also applies to the processing of digital personal data outside the territory of India, if such processing is in connection with any activity related to offering of goods or services to Data Principals within the territory of India.

This Act does not apply to:
- Personal data processed by an individual for any personal or domestic purpose
- Personal data that is made or caused to be made publicly available by the Data Principal to whom such personal data relates, or by any other person who is under an obligation under any law to make such personal data publicly available

subsections.title: Territorial Scope
subsections.content: The Act applies to processing of digital personal data within India, and also to processing outside India if connected to offering goods or services to Data Principals in India.

subsections.title: Exclusions
subsections.content: The Act does not apply to personal data processed for purely personal or domestic purposes, or to personal data that has been made publicly available.

citations: Section 3, Digital Personal Data Protection Act, 2023

stakeholders.title: Stakeholders and Definitions
stakeholders.content:
Key definitions under the Act:

Data Principal means the individual to whom the personal data relates and where such individual is a child, includes the parents or lawful guardian of such a child.

Data Fiduciary means any person who alone or in conjunction with other persons determines the purpose and means of processing of personal data.

Data Processor means any person who processes personal data on behalf of a Data Fiduciary.

Personal Data means any data about an individual who is identifiable by or in relation to such data.

Digital Personal Data means personal data in digital form.

Processing in relation to personal data, means an automated operation or set of operations performed on digital personal data, and includes operations such as collection, recording, organisation, structuring, storage, adaptation, retrieval, use, alignment or combination, indexing, disclosure by transmission, dissemination or otherwise making available, restriction, erasure or destruction.

subsections.title: Data Principal
subsections.content: The individual whose personal data is being processed. For children (persons below 18 years), the Data Principal includes their parents or lawful guardians.

subsections.title: Data Fiduciary
subsections.content: Any person who determines the purpose and means of processing personal data. This includes entities that collect, store, or use personal data.

subsections.title: Data Processor
subsections.content: Any person who processes personal data on behalf of a Data Fiduciary, acting under the instructions of the Data Fiduciary.

citations: Section 2, Digital Personal Data Protection Act, 2023

obligations.title: Obligations of Data Fiduciary
obligations.content:
Every Data Fiduciary shall be responsible for complying with the provisions of this Act in respect of any processing undertaken by it or on its behalf by a Data Processor.

A Data Fiduciary may process the personal data of a Data Principal only in accordance with the provisions of this Act and the rules made thereunder, for a lawful purpose, andâ€”
(a) for which the Data Principal has given her consent; or
(b) for certain legitimate uses.

Every Data Fiduciary shall, before processing the personal data of a Data Principal, give to the Data Principal a notice informing her, in clear and plain language, about the personal data to be collected and the purpose for which the personal data is to be processed.

Every Data Fiduciary and Data Processor shall implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to ensure effective implementation of the provisions of this Act.

In case of a personal data breach, the Data Fiduciary shall notify the Board and each affected Data Principal, of such breach in such form and manner as may be prescribed.

subsections.title: Lawful Purpose for Processing
subsections.content: A Data Fiduciary may process personal data only for a lawful purpose for which the Data Principal has given consent, or for certain legitimate uses as specified in the Act.

subsections.title: Notice Requirements
subsections.content: Every Data Fiduciary shall give to the Data Principal a notice informing about the personal data to be collected and the purpose for which it is to be processed.

subsections.title: Consent Management
subsections.content: Consent given by the Data Principal shall be free, specific, informed, unconditional, and unambiguous. The Data Principal shall have the right to withdraw consent at any time.

subsections.title: Security Safeguards
subsections.content: Every Data Fiduciary and Data Processor shall implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to ensure effective implementation of the provisions of this Act.

citations: Sections 4-9, Digital Personal Data Protection Act, 2023

rights.title: Rights of Data Principal
rights.content:
A Data Principal shall have the right to obtain from the Data Fiduciary a summary of personal data being processed and the processing activities undertaken with respect to such personal data.

A Data Principal shall have the right to correction of inaccurate or misleading personal data, completion of incomplete personal data, updating of personal data, and erasure of personal data that is no longer necessary for the purpose for which it was processed.

A Data Principal shall have the right to register a grievance with the Data Fiduciary in such manner and within such period as may be prescribed.

A Data Principal may, by way of a legal instrument, nominate any other individual who shall, in the event of death or incapacity of the Data Principal, exercise the rights of the Data Principal under this Act.

subsections.title: Right to Access Information
subsections.content: A Data Principal has the right to obtain from the Data Fiduciary a summary of personal data being processed and the processing activities undertaken.

subsections.title: Right to Correction and Erasure
subsections.content: A Data Principal has the right to correction of inaccurate or misleading personal data, completion of incomplete personal data, updating of personal data, and erasure of personal data.

subsections.title: Right to Grievance Redressal
subsections.content: A Data Principal has the right to register a grievance with the Data Fiduciary. The Data Fiduciary shall respond to such grievance within the prescribed period.

subsections.title: Right to Nominate
subsections.content: A Data Principal may nominate any other individual who shall, in the event of death or incapacity, exercise the rights of the Data Principal.

citations: Sections 10-14, Digital Personal Data Protection Act, 2023

dataBreach.title: Personal Data Breach
dataBreach.content: A personal data breach means any unauthorised processing of personal data or accidental disclosure, acquisition, sharing, use, alteration, destruction of or loss of access to personal data, that compromises the confidentiality, integrity or availability of personal data.

subsections.title: Obligation to Prevent Data Breach
subsections.content: Every Data Fiduciary and Data Processor shall implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to ensure effective implementation of the provisions of this Act, including measures to ensure that personal data is processed in accordance with the provisions of this Act.

subsections.title: Obligations in Case of Personal Data Breach
subsections.content: In case of a personal data breach, the Data Fiduciary shall notify the Board and each affected Data Principal, of such breach in such form and manner as may be prescribed. The Data Fiduciary shall clearly and concisely inform the Data Principal about the nature of the personal data breach, the consequences of the breach, and the measures being taken or proposed to be taken by the Data Fiduciary to address the breach.

citations: Section 8, Digital Personal Data Protection Act, 2023

exemptions.title: Exemptions

subsections.title: General Exemptions
subsections.content: The Act provides exemptions for processing necessary for legal rights, judicial functions, prevention of offences, research purposes, and for startups as notified.

subsections.title: State Security Exemptions
subsections.content: The Central Government may exempt any instrumentality of the State from application of the Act in the interest of sovereignty, security, public order, etc.

citations: Section 17, Digital Personal Data Protection Act, 2023

regulatory.title: Data Protection Board of India

subsections.title: Establishment of Data Protection Board
subsections.content: The Central Government shall establish a Data Protection Board of India to exercise powers and perform functions under this Act.

subsections.title: Functions of the Board
subsections.content: The Board shall monitor compliance, direct remedial measures, inquire into breaches, impose penalties, and hear complaints from Data Principals.

subsections.title: Powers of the Board
subsections.content: The Board has powers similar to a civil court for summoning persons, requiring documents, and issuing commissions.

citations: Sections 18-28, Digital Personal Data Protection Act, 2023

penalties.title: Penalties and Adjudication
penalties.content:
If the Board determines, after conducting an inquiry, that a person has failed to comply with the provisions of this Act or the rules made thereunder, it may, after giving such person a reasonable opportunity of being heard, impose such penalty as it thinks fit.

Penalties may be imposed for:
- Failure to fulfill obligations in relation to children or Significant Data Fiduciary: up to two hundred crore rupees
- Failure to notify the Board and Data Principals of a data breach: up to two hundred crore rupees
- Non-compliance with directions issued by the Board: up to two hundred crore rupees
- Other contraventions: up to ten thousand rupees for each instance

The Board shall have regard to the nature, gravity and duration of the breach, the type and nature of personal data affected, repetitive nature of the breach, and whether the breach was intentional or negligent, while determining the penalty.

subsections.title: Penalty Structure
subsections.content: Penalties range from ten thousand rupees for minor contraventions to two hundred crore rupees for serious breaches, particularly those involving children or Significant Data Fiduciaries.

subsections.title: Adjudication Process
subsections.content: The Board may, after giving the person concerned a reasonable opportunity of being heard, impose such penalty as it thinks fit. The Board may also direct the person to take such measures as it may specify to remedy the contravention.

citations: Section 33, Digital Personal Data Protection Act, 2023
